children.NodeDescription:
///t
Proposal[SY1]
t///
///h
h///

///t
The impact of continuity of care on medication adherence
t///
///h
h///

///t
Shenzhen YAO
t///
///h
h///

///t
Background
t///
///h
h///

///t
Continuity of care has been linked to medication adherence; however, in previous studies the association may have been underestimated.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Objectives
t///
///h
h///

///t
1) Objective 1: To investigate the extent to which the high usual provider continuity index, usual statin prescriber status, and complete medical examination provision occurred together on the same GP of a patient (i.e., a new statin user); and 2) To assess performance of models using different measures of continuity of care as predictors of statin medication adherence.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Methods
t///
///h
h///

///t
Design: A retrospective cohort study.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Source of data: Administrative databases of Saskatchewan (SK), Canada
t///
///h
h///

///t
Population: SK adults who initialized blood-lipid-lowering medications between January 1, 2012, and December 31, 2017.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Outcome: Optimal medication adherence, defined as the proportion of days covered >= 80% within one year since the first dispensation of a statin.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Measures of continuity of care: 1) Continuity of care based on GP claims only (i.e., the usual provider continuity index); 2) A comprehensive continuity of care index developed by investigators; and 3) an integrated index (i.e., a measure incorporating UPC index, and status of comprehensive continuity of care).
t///
///h
h///

///t
Data analyses: Proposed details below. To be confirmed by committee.
t///
///h
h///

///t

AUC

Area Under the (ROC) Curve

CME

Complete Medical Examination

CMEP

Complete Medical Examination Provider

DIN

Drug Identification Number

GP

General Practitioner

NRI index

Net Reclassification Improvement index

PDC

Proportion of Days Covered

ROC

Receiver Operating Characteristic

SK

Saskatchewan

UPCI

Usual Provider Continuity index

USP

Usual Statin Prescriber


t///
///h
h///

///t
Studies suggest that continuity of care provided by physicians is associated with improved medication adherence.(1-4) The precise nature of this association is unknown but is likely mediated by factors promoting a strong relationship between patients and physicians.(5, 6) Indeed, an ongoing relationship between a physician and a patient is associated with higher satisfaction, improved trust, and effective communication from the patient receiving primary care.(7) Having a single physician also helps ensure the completeness of patients�� health records, and can facilitate the coordination of disease management.(8)
t///
///h
h///

///t
Continuity of care is a complex concept.(9) Although previous studies have demonstrated a positive correlation with adherence, conventional measures of continuity of care have theoretical limitations that may be improved upon using a more comprehensive definition that is specific for medication adherence.(1-4) For example, continuity of care is commonly measured by the usual provider continuity index (i.e., UPCI) .(9, 10) UPCI is determined by a simple calculation of the percentage of visits to the most frequently visited physician relative to all other physician visits in a given time period. (9, 10) As a result, it is highly influenced by total number of visits, and total number of different physicians.(10) For example, a patient with multiple chronic conditions may visit many different physicians in a given year. In this situation, the UPCI for that patient��s regular physician may be low because the denominator (i.e., total number of visits with all physicians) is increased compared to a different patient who visits a single physician exclusively. Moreover, since the UPCI is based solely on visit occurrences, the nature of the visits is not accounted for. For example, the UPCI does not consider prescribing activities; individuals are more likely to be adherent to medications that are prescribed from a usual provider.(11) UPCI also does not identify the clinical services performed during visits. For example, a yearly complete medical examination (CME) would be expected from a patient��s usual physician. Although few studies have examined the impact of CME providers on medication adherence; this activity has been identified as a measure of continuity of care.(12, 13)
t///
///h
h///

///t
Currently, the UPCI is the most widely used measure of continuity of care when examining medication adherence despite lacking information on patient-related activities such as prescribing or performing annual check-ups. We hypothesized that including these clinical activities as additional dimensions of the continuity of care definition would result in greater specificity in identification of effective relationships, produce a stronger association with medication adherence, and improve the predictive ability of medication adherence models. The objectives of this study were: 1) to determine the extent to which the traditional measure of continuity of care, the UPCI, identifies physician-patient relationships that include medication prescribing and provision of complete medical; and 2) To assess performance of models using different measures of continuity of care as predictors of statin medication adherence.
t///
///h
h///

///t
A retrospective cohort of patients receiving statin medications was identified using population-based administrative health databases. Statin medications (i.e., HMG CoA reductase inhibitors) are an ideal choice for adherence research for several reasons: they are prescribed for long-term use; they have no therapeutic equivalent so switching to another class is typically discouraged; they are prescribed to a large percentage of the population in North America; they are indicated for long term use; and they are associated with reduced morbidity and mortality from atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Data were extracted from administrative databases in the province of Saskatchewan, Canada. These databases include a patient registration file, a physician service claims file, a hospital discharge abstract database, and a prescription drug claims file. The Patient registration file captures birth, sex, rurality, registry start/end dates, and residence-based income quintile estimation of residents in Saskatchewan. The physician service claims file captures service claims by physicians to patients. The hospital discharge abstract database captures hospitalization events. The prescription drug claims file capture dispensations of prescription medications. The claims include medications covered by the drug plan of Saskatchewan (i.e., adjudicated), and those not covered (i.e., non-adjudicated[BD5] ) .(14)
t///
///h
h///

///t
The study participants were individuals who newly initiated a statin medication (i.e., using a five year washout period) between January 1, 2012, and December 31, 2017. The date of receiving the first dispensation of a statin medication was defined as the index date. Several exclusion criteria were applied before assembling the final cohort, including: 1) missing age or sex information in the patient registration file; 2) less than 18 years old on the index date; 3) not continuously registered as a beneficiary of the provincial health plan during the washout period or the follow-up period of 365 days; 4) deceased, or termination of benefits during the follow-up period; 5) admitted to a long term care facility within the washout or follow-up period; 6) admitted to an out-province facility for acute care during follow-up); 7) pregnant (ICD-9: 291,292,303-305; ICD-10: F10-F19, F55) w[BD6] ithin the run-in or the follow-up;(15) 8) never visited a GP during the follow-up period; 9) individuals for whom their prescriber has no information available for age and sex.
t///
///h
h///

///t
First, a baseline run-in period was defined as 365 days prior to the index date and was used to define the baseline characteristics of the study cohort. Second, a follow-up period was defined as 365 days since (inclusive) the index date. In addition, a washout period was defined as 1,825 days prior to the index date for exclusion of prevalent statin users.
t///
///h
h///

children.name: Continuity of care measures and physician classifications

children.NodeDescription:
///t
For each individual, we independently measured continuity of care using different approaches (specific methods to follow): a) the usual care provider based on the UPCI;(9, 10) b) the usual statin prescriber (USP); c) complete medical examination provider (CMEP);(12) and d) a comprehensive continuity of care measure that integrates all measures above.
t///
///h
h///

///t
For each individual, a usual care provider was identified as the GP physician with the highest UPCI. In cases where a tie was observed, more than one GP were identified as the usual care providers. The UPCI value was calculated by the following formula:(10)  UPCI = /span>; where ni = the number of encounters between the individual and the usual care provider within the follow-up period and N = the total number of encounters between the individual and all his/her GP physicians within the same period.  The median UPCI value was used to stratify individuals into high or low groups, representing the relative number of visits provided by the usual care provider.
t///
///h
h///

///t
A physician encounter was defined as a distinct service claim between a GP physician and a patient on a particular date (i.e., multiple claims were treated as one encounter if they were from the same GP for the same patient on the same date).(10) Service claims included the specialty of the care providers, from which GP physicians were identified. Service claims were not counted if: 1) the claim was marked as invalid; 2) if the service was provided to a hospitalized patient; or 3) if the claim originated from an out-of-province provider.
t///
///h
h///

///t
A usual statin prescriber (USP) was defined as the prescriber who was the most frequently identified from an individual��s statin dispensation claims during the follow-up period. In cases where a tie was observed, more than one physician was identified as the USP. Complete medical examination providers (CMEP) were identified as GP physicians claiming a complete medical examination (CME) in the fee-for-service claims file during the follow-up period (fee codes B003, B064, B052, or B004). An individual could have multiple CMEPs within the study period.(12) Finally, we integrated these individual definitions into a comprehensive continuity of care measure defined as individuals who received all of the following services from a single GP physician during the one year follow-up period: 1) the usual care provider (i.e., with the highest UPCI); 2) the usual statin prescriber (USP); and 3) the provider of a complete medical examination (CMEP).(12)
t///
///h
h///

///t
We calculated the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and the Kappa statistics(16) of the high UPCI measure for predicting the usual statin prescriber (USP), the CMEP, as well as the occurrence of comprehensive continuity of care where all measures of provided by the same physician (i.e., high UPCI, USP, and CMEP). These predictive analyses were also conducted after stratifying the usual care providers based on their UPCI value into high or low (i.e., above or below the median UPCI value).
t///
///h
h///

///t
Logistic regression models were created to test the effect of different measures of continuity of care on the probability of optimal adherence to statin medications at one year. Continuity of care measures were examined using three approaches: 1) high / low UPCI value (i.e., above/below the median value);(4, 10) and 2) comprehensive continuity of care (i.e., single physician identified as high UPCI, USP, and CMEP).
t///
///h
h///

///t
Each of the two continuity of care measures were tested separately in a multivariable model examining the occurrence of optimal statin adherence at one-year. Medication adherence was measured by the proportion of days covered (PDC),(17) which was calculated between the index date (i.e., first dispensation) and the following 365 days for each individual. Briefly, the number of days supplied during this time was estimated from the total quantity of tablets dispensed assuming one tablet per day dosing. Quantities dispensed near the end of the follow-up period were truncated based on the number of days remaining. Switching between statins was allowed. The total number of statin days supplied was divided by 365 days (minus days spent in hospital for acute care) to obtain the adherence percentage. Optimal adherence was defined as PDC>= 80%.(18) Details of the PDC method have been described in the literature.(17, 18)
t///
///h
h///

///t
Prior to testing the continuity of care measures, a baseline adherence model was constructed using a wide array of covariates that are traditionally used in predicting medication adherence using population-based data.(19) These covariates were organized under a framework described by five general categories: patient-related, socioeconomic-related, disease-related, treatment related, and healthcare system-related factors.(19) Patient-related covariates included age on the index date, residence (rural/urban) on the index date. Socioeconomic-related covariates included income level (i.e., the neighborhood median household income quintile: lowest=1, highest=5).(20, 21) Disease related covariates included number of hospitalizations, number of out-patient visits, number of emergency department visits, Charlson comorbidity score, and status of individual chronic conditions (yes/no for each condition). The chronic conditions were identified using methods provided by the Canadian Chronic Disease Surveillance System.(15) The treatment related covariates included number of distinct prescription medications (i.e., by DIN). The healthcare system related covariates included percentage of prescription medication cost paid by government health insurance. This baseline model represented our best approach to explaining the phenomenon of poor medication adherence using currently known predictor variables.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Univariate models containing each continuity of care measure were constructed on optimal adherence separately prior to the addition of covariates from the baseline adherence model. Multicollinearity between the continuity of care variable, and the covariates (i.e., variables not for continuity of care) were examined by the variance inflation factor (VIF) obtained from a regression model. If the VIF value was greater than 2.5, the covariate was removed.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Next, we compared the prediction performance of each continuity of care measure in predicting medication adherence based on receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, using the Delong test.(22)
t///
///h
h///

///t
To test the stability of our results, several subgroup and sensitivity analyses were conducted. In subgroup analyses, we assessed the impact of a comprehensive continuity of care measure among individuals with a high UPCI as well as a low UPCI. We also assessed the impact of high UPCI among individuals with or without comprehensive continuity of care. We also conducted sensitivity analyses for the adherence measure, which was recalculated without allowing accumulated supplies between refills. We also changed the threshold for ��low�� UPCI level to the 25th and 75th percentile rather than the median. SAS statistical software, version 9.4, (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA) was used to conduct all analyses.(23)
t///
///h
h///

///t
Overall 180,010 individuals received statin medications between January 1, 2012, and December 31, 2017. Among them, 21,149 were excluded for missing demographic information, death during the study period, or lacking continuous beneficiary status. Of the 58,549 individuals who were defined as new statin users, 3,405 (5.8%) were excluded for admission to a nursing home facility, staying in an out-of-province hospital, pregnancy, or having zero service claims by a GP within the follow-up period. The final cohort was comprised of 55,144 new users of statin medications (Figure 1). Briefly, the median age of the cohort was 59.0 years (25th percentile=51.0, 75th percentile = 67.0), and 44.2 percent (24,385/55,144) were females. Also, 32.3% (17,811/55,144) lived in a rural setting. The median number of encounters to any GP during the one-year follow-up period was 6.0 (25th percentile=3.0, 75th percentile=9.0).
t///
///h
h///

///t
A single usual care provider (i.e., the GP with the highest UPCI) could be identified for 92.6% (n=51,071) of the cohort, whereas 7.4% (n=4,073) of individuals had two or more GP physicians tied for the highest UPCI. The median UPCI among the usual care providers was 0.82 (25th percentile = 0.62, 75th percentile=1.00). In other words, half of the identified usual care providers were responsible for 82% to 100% of all GP visits with their specific patients. Similarly, a single ��usual statin prescriber�� (USP) could be identified for the vast majority of individuals (52,693, 95.6%). However, only 39.9% of the cohort members received complete medical examinations from a GP physician. The rest of the cohort members either never had complete medical examinations during the follow-up period, or received the examinations from a specialist. Finally, 15,579 (28.3%) of the cohort members were classified as receiving comprehensive continuity of care.
t///
///h
h///

///t
A high UPCI was neither a sensitive or specific marker of any of the GP physician activities among our study individuals [Table 2]. The sensitivity ranged from 0.55, 95% CI 0.55 to 0.56 (using UPCI to determine usual care providers) to 0.60[BD7] . The specificity ranged from 0.52, 95% CI 0.51 to 0.52 (to determine CMEP) to 0.61[BD8] [Table 2]. These indices did not improve in a subgroup of usual care providers-patients with high UPCI (i.e., above the median value).
t///
///h
h///

///t
Both high UPCI and comprehensive continuity of care showed statistically significant effects on optimal adherence to statin medications. The odds of optimal statin adherence was significantly higher for individuals receiving continuity of care defined by a high UPCI (unadjusted OR = 1.28, 95% CI 1.24 to 1.32, adjusted OR =1.23, 95% CI 1.19 to 1.28). A stronger effect was observed when the comprehensive continuity of care measure was used (unadjusted OR = 1.45, 95% CI 1.40 to 1.51, adjusted OR=1. 56, 95% CI 1.50 to 1.63).
t///
///h
h///

///t
Comprehensive continuity of care was associated with a similar improvement in optimal adherence among subgroups with a high UPCI (adjusted OR=1.48, 95% CI 1.40 to 1.56) as well as those with low UPCI values (adjusted OR=1.60, 95% CI 1.51 to 1.70). In contrast, the impact of a high UPCI appeared to have a weaker impact when tested in subgroups based on the presence or absence of comprehensive continuity of care (OR 1.13 (95% CI 1. 06 to 1.21) and OR 1.22 (95% CI 1.17 to 1.27) respectively) [Table 3]. In addition, the comprehensive continuity of care seems to be a more important factor. Individuals presenting comprehensive continuity of care while having a low UPCI score were 31% more likely to be adherent comparing to those with a higher UPCI score but did not present comprehensive continuity of care (OR = 1.31, 95%CI 1.24 to 1.39).
t///
///h
h///

///t
The DeLong test was performed to determine if the inclusion of the comprehensive continuity of care measure (versus the UPCI index) improved the predictive power of a multivariate adherence model with a wide selection of covariates.(22) The model with the comprehensive continuity of care term was significantly better (the area under the ROC curve increased by 0.006, ��2 statistic = 38.8, p < 0.0001) as opposed to the model including the UPCI measure of continuity of care.
t///
///h
h///

///t
In sensitivity analyses, the effect of UPCI and comprehensive continuity of care were similar to the primary analysis when the days supply of statin medications were not allowed to be accumulated between refills. The effect of UPCI seemed to be sensitive to the threshold of the UPCI levels. Also, we raised the threshold to define ��high UCPI�� from the median value to the 25th percentile. In this case the association of the UPCI measure on optimal adherence was stronger (adjusted OR = 1.39, 95% CI 1.34 to 1.45) but weaker when the threshold was lowered to the 75th percentile (adjusted OR = 1.09, 95% CI 1.05 to 1.13). However, the impact of the UPCI was still weaker than the effect by the comprehensive continuity of care term regardless of the threshold changes.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Continuity of care measured by UPCI has been shown as a predictor of medication adherence in the literature.(1-4) However, UPCI is derived exclusively from the number of physician visits and could theoretically be improved upon by capturing the nature of physician activities to a given patient. Our study confirmed that UPCI was not a sensitive or specific measure for the identification of other possible services relating to continuity of care. Furthermore, the addition of these clinical activities to the definition of continuity of care resulted in a stronger association with medication adherence and significantly improved the predictive power of a medication adherence model. Population-based models of medication adherence have identified numerous individual associations over the years but remain notoriously poor at explaining the overall variance between individuals who remain adherent and those who do not. Thus, our findings do not merely identify a new variable for models of medication adherence but they contribute to an important and elusive goal of understanding the phenomenon within a well-accepted framework that remains highly theoretical[BD9] .
t///
///h
h///

///t
Despite[SY10] that a vast number of possible determinants of medication adherence have been examined in the literature, these factors virtually always have weak predictability in multivariable models.(24-26) Wong and colleagues conducted a population-based study, including many patient-level factors that are typically available in administrative databases.(25) These factors included demographic characteristics (e.g., age, sex, and marital status), comorbidities (e.g., vascular disease, mental illness, and chronic lung or renal disorders), and regimen complexity. The study also included clinical factors such as disease severity, and laboratory test results. Yet the authors found that all these variables only explained 2.9% of the adherence variation.(25) As a result, the research into factors of medication adherence should not focus only on the statistical significance, but also the predictively of the model itself. In this situation, the comprehensive continuity of care measure in our study resulted in improvement of predictive ability.
t///
///h
h///

///t
[BD11] The superiority of the comprehensive continuity of care measure over the traditional UPCI approach was clearly evident in our results. Overall, the comprehensive continuity of care measure presented a strong effect as opposed to the UPCI measure. The stratified analyses showed that, regardless of high/low UPCI scores, the presence of comprehensive continuity of care added significant discrimination of individuals who ultimately exhibited optimal adherence. In addition, the comprehensive continuity of care seems to be a more important factor. Individuals presenting comprehensive continuity of care while having a low UPCI score were more likely to be adherent comparing to those with a higher UPCI score but did not present comprehensive continuity of care[SY12] .
t///
///h
h///

///t
Our study was not without limitations. First, the effect of continuity of care on adherence was not adjusted by GP-related characteristics (i.e., a GP's age, sex, medical training background, workload, and prescribing habits). The literature suggests that these characteristics may affect medication adherence.(11-13, 27)GP-related characteristics have to be obtained from a single GP for an individual. In our study, individuals not having comprehensive continuity of care were treated by multiple GPs. It was impossible to determine which GP's characteristics to be used in the study. Different approaches should be taken in future studies (e.g., investigating the impact of a usual prescriber's characteristics to medication adherence, adjusted by comprehensive continuity of care status).
t///
///h
h///

///t
Second, the study data could be incomplete. Canadian GPs were paid by a fee-for-service (FFS) mechanism, or a non-fee-for-service (NFFS) mechanism (i.e., paid by a salary).(28) GPs paid by the NFFS mechanism are not mandatory to submit service claims. Number of visits to these GPS may be underestimated, and they are less likely to be identified as the usual care provider than GPs paid by FFS mechanism. The impact by such underestimation on precise measure of continuity of care is unknown, which should be explored in future studies.
t///
///h
h///

///t
Thirdly, the association between continuity of care measures and medication adherence may not be causal. Having all services from the same GP could be a sign of a good relationship that already exists; therefore medication adherence was not caused by continuity of care, rather by a trustful relationship also caused continuity of care. Nonetheless, continuity of care measures can be a proxy of trustful relationship, and have been used in many studies on medication adherence. (1-4)
t///
///h
h///

///t
In conclusion, our study suggests that the proposed comprehensive continuity of care measure is a stronger predictor of medication adherence. Researchers should consider using the comprehensive measure, instead of the traditional UPCI measure, when investigating the association between continuity of care and medication adherence. For primary care practice, our study sent an important message to GPs that providing multiple services to their patients has benefits on medication adherence. In conclusion, our study suggests that the proposed comprehensive continuity of care measure is a stronger predictor of medication adherence. Researchers should consider using the comprehensive measure, instead of the traditional UPC index measure, when investigating the association between continuity of care and medication adherence. For primary care practice, our study sent an important message to GPs that providing multiple services to their patients has benefits on medication adherence.
t///
///h
h///

///t

///t
*In the adjusted model, the covariates included age on the index date, residence (rural/urban) on the index date, income level (i.e., the neighborhood median household income quintile: lowest=1, highest=5), number of hospitalizations, number of out-patient visits, number of emergency department visits, Charlson comorbidity score, status of individual chronic conditions, number of distinct prescription medications (i.e., by DIN), and percentage of prescription medication cost paid by government health insurance.
